#Text=How to Grow Basil
#Text=Three Methods : Starting Seeds Caring for Basil Harvesting and Using Basil
#Text=Basil is easy to grow , and transforms ordinary meals into culinary treasures !
#Text=Fresh basil not only tastes better than dried , it actually tastes different , almost as if it were not the same herb .
#Text=This article outlines how to plant and harvest basil .
#Text=Method 1 of 3 : Starting Seeds
#Text=1 Choose the kind of basil you wish to grow .
#Text=Basil comes in many different varieties , each of which have a unique flavor and smell .
#Text=Read up on different types of basil and pick out one - or several - that appeal to you , then order the seeds or buy them at a garden store .
#Text=Here are a few ideas :
#Text=Cinnamon basil really does smell like the sweet spice , and it also has unusually beautiful and fragrant flowers .
#Text=Lemon basil actually contains citral , an aromatic compound found in citrus fruit , and smells very lemony .
#Text=Purple basil is often grown for decoration , as well as its scent and flowers .

#Text=There are perennial basils which come back year after year , like African Blue Basil ( which has pretty blue veins on its leaves ) and Thai Basil , while most other varieties are annuals , which you 'll have to plant year after year .
#Text=Globe and Greek basil are much more difficult to grow , but form pretty little bushes which stay well-contained .
#Text=2 Start seed indoors four to six weeks before last frost .
#Text=Basil needs warm air and sun to do well , so it 's often easiest to start the seeds indoors instead of risking that they 'll get damaged by frost .
#Text=If you live in a hot climate , you can start the seeds outside instead .
#Text=To figure out when the last frost will be , consult an almanac or talk with other gardeners in your area .
#Text=3 Prepare seed containers .
#Text=Fill flats or individual seed containers with a mixture of equal parts perlite , vermiculite , and peat .
#Text=Press the mixture slightly to eliminate air pockets .
#Text=Dampen the mixture with water so it 's ready to provide the right environment for the basil seeds to germinate .
#Text=4 Plant the seeds .
#Text=Drop one to two seeds into each container .
#Text=Cover them lightly with soil .
#Text=Cover containers with clear plastic kitchen wrap , so they stay moist .
#Text=Leave the containers in a sunny window .
#Text=Twice daily , remove the plastic wrap and sprinkle the containers with more water .
#Text=5 Remove the plastic wrap when the sprouts emerge .
#Text=When you see the first green tendrils push up through the soil , it 's time to remove the plastic wrap .
#Text=Keep watering the sprouts twice daily , never letting the soil dry out .
#Text=When the plants become a few inches tall and their leaves mature , it 's time to transplant them to a larger container .
#Text=Method 2 of 3 : Caring for Basil
#Text=1 Transplant the basil plants .
#Text=Once two sets of leaves have formed , basil can be planted into the garden or permanent containers .
#Text=Basil does not tolerate frost so do n't plant too early .
#Text=It 's best to put basil somewhere where it will get a good deal of sunshine and have well-drained soil .
#Text=To plant the basil in the garden , dig holes spaced at least 6 inches apart .
#Text=Place the roots in the holes and place soil around the stems .
#Text=Pat down soil around the plants to eliminate air pockets .
#Text=If you want to plant the basil in a container , make sure it 's large enough to accommodate the number of plants you 're growing ;
#Text=they need to be planted 6 inches apart , since they grow quite large .
#Text=2 Keep the soil damp , but not soaked .
#Text=Basil does best in well-drained soil , and should not be subjected to standing water .
#Text=Water the mature basil plants once a day , in the morning , so the water has time to soak in and evaporate rather than sitting on the plants overnight .
#Text=3 Pinch off flower heads .
#Text=When you see flower buds , pinch them and two pairs of leaves under them off .
#Text=Flowers blooming create a hormone change which dramatically reduces the flavor of the leaves , as well as reducing the amount of foliage which grows .
#Text=This is called " bolting " and is more likely to happen when there 's extra sunshine .
#Text=You 'll notice that if you leave the flowers , the plant will become lanky and the leaves wo n't be as full or tasty .
#Text=4 Watch for pests and mold .
#Text=Basil plants are attractive to Japanese beetles
#Text=the best way to control these pests is to pick them off the plants by hand .
#Text=If your plants show signs of mold growth , they may not be getting adequate sunlight , or they may be too close together .
#Text=Weed out the smaller plants to give the larger ones more space .
#Text=Method 3 of 3 : Harvesting and Using Basil
#Text=1 Harvest and prune .
#Text=As the plant matures , pinch off the top two pairs of leaves once a stalk reaches a reasonable height .
#Text=If you look closely , at the base of every leaf are two tiny little leaves that will grow outwards if the stem growing between them is cut off .
#Text=Cut close to those tiny leaves , but be sure not to damage them .
#Text=Pinching encourages the plant 's energy to be directed into its stronger stems and leaves .
#Text=This helps the plants grow bushy .
#Text=Do n't pinch on the lower part of the stem , or the basil plants will grow tall and reedy .
#Text=You want them to get bushy , so pinch from the top .
#Text=2 Enjoy the basil fresh .
#Text=Rinse off the leaves and use the basil to make pesto or a Caprese salad with tomatoes and fresh mozzarella cheese .
#Text=3 Store the basil in the refrigerator .
#Text=You 'll probably have more basil than you could possibly eat fresh , so plan on storing some in the fridge .
#Text=Wash the leaves , dry them well , and wrap them in paper towels .
#Text=Place them in a food storage container with an airtight lid .
#Text=4 Freeze the basil .
#Text=Freezing the leaves whole does n't work very well , but if you puree it first you can freeze it for months .
#Text=Place the basil in a blender with a little water .
#Text=Puree it until smooth , then put it in a food storage bag and freeze until you need it .
